required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Postoperative Belladonna and Morphine Suppositories in Vaginal Surgery
clinical_study.official_title: Randomized Clinical Trial of Postoperative Belladonna and Morphine Suppositories in Vaginal Surgery

brief_summary.textblock: Our primary aim is to determine whether the routine use of belladonna and morphine suppositories will improve pain control following vaginal surgery. Treatment will begin immediately following surgery and every 8 hours for 16 hours.

detailed_description.textblock:
Minimizing postoperative pain is vital to a successful surgical recovery. Inadequate pain control may result in nausea, vomiting, an extended hospital stay, and reduced patient satisfaction. Oral and parenteral narcotics are commonly used for pain relief and their use may exacerbate the incidence of sedation, nausea, and vomiting; ultimately delaying convalescence. Previous studies have demonstrated that rectal analgesia following surgery results in lower pain scores and less intravenous morphine consumption. Belladonna and opium suppositories are routinely prescribed at our institution and their efficacy has not been confirmed.
A prospective, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial will be undertaken using belladonna and opium rectal suppositories following vaginal surgery. Treatment will begin immediately following surgery and continue every 8 hours for a total of 3 doses.

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.description: Pain at 4 hours was recorded using a linear analog pain scale, with 0 being "no pain," and 10 being "worst pain imaginable."

secondary_outcome.description: Pain at 12 hours was recorded using a linear analog pain scale, with 0 being "no pain," and 10 being "worst pain imaginable."
Pain at 20 hours was recorded using a linear analog pain scale, with 0 being "no pain," and 10 being "worst pain imaginable."
Use of all ancillary narcotic medications was taken from the medical record.
This information was taken from the medical record.
This information was taken from the medical record.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Times Antiemetic Rescue Medication Was Used
Number of Subjects Who Used Antiemetic Rescue Medications

secondary_outcome.description: Patient satisfaction with pain relief was evaluated 24 hours after surgery using a linear analog satisfaction scale, with 0 being "very dissatisfied," and 10 being "very satisfied."

arm_group.description: Belladonna (16.2 mg) and opium (60 mg) suppositories administered rectally immediately following surgery and every 8 hours for 16 hours for a total of 3 doses.
Placebo suppositories administered rectally immediately following surgery and every 8 hours for 16 hours for a total of 3 doses.

intervention.description: Belladonna (16.2 mg) and opium (60 mg) suppositories administered rectally immediately following surgery and every 8 hours for 16 hours for a total of 3 doses.
Placebo suppositories administered rectally immediately following surgery and every 8 hours for 16 hours for a total of 3 doses.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Scheduled for elective vaginal surgery requiring general anesthesia at the Mayo Clinic Hospital. This would include a vaginal hysterectomy with culdoplasty or post-hysterectomy prolapse repair, including culdoplasty with or without anterior/posterior repair.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Participation in another trial using an investigational product.
- Pregnancy.
- Scheduled for a non-vaginal surgical procedure.
- Scheduled for a robotic hysterectomy.
- Scheduled to have combined surgeries (vaginal surgery plus another non-vaginal surgery).
- There is a known hypersensitivity to belladonna and/or opium.
- Contraindication to narcotic use.
- Chronic pain with preoperative pain score greater than 4 out of 10 points.
- Clinically significant substance abuse.
- Mental condition that may impair the ability to provide study assessments.

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Subjects were recruited at the Mayo Clinic in Arizona, United States from January 2011 to April 2013.

measure.title: Preoperative Pain
measure.description: Pain was recorded on a validated numeric pain scale (1-10), with 0 = no pain and 10 = worst pain imaginable. Not all participants completed the pain scale, therefore the populations analyzed were Belladonna and Morphine Suppository Arm (N=39), Placebo Suppository Arm (N=45).

reported_events.time_frame: Subjects will be followed for 24 hours after surgery, and the research coordinator will assess for adverse events one week after surgery via the electronic medical record.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: All Principal Investigators ARE employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
